Headline.Para: Investing under CPFIS: Good to lower costs but tweaks needed

LeadPara.Para: Early this month, the Government announced that it will lower the costs of investing retirement funds under the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS).
The move was generally welcomed as it would help to improve investment returns and counter the undesirable practice of "churning".

TailParas.Para: On the flip side, this could result in retail investors not receiving the needed advice they need in investment planning as financial advisory (FA) reps are no longer compensated for doing so, said Mr Roland Yeo, president of the Insurance and Financial Practitioners Association of Singapore.

This sentiment was also echoed by Mr David Choo, president of the Association of Financial Advisers (Singapore), who said that the initiative to lower investment costs will "deprive many investors of the advice and service of FA reps".
They were reacting to the news that the sales charge and wrap fee imposed under the CPFIS would be cut in two phases, the first from Oct 1.

Sales charges for new purchases of CPFIS products, such as investment-linked insurance policies (ILPs) and unit trusts, will first fall from 3 per cent to 1.5 per cent. This charge will then be removed from Oct 1 next year.
In addition, the cap on annual wrap fees will be lowered to 0.7 per cent per annum this Oct 1, and to 0.4 per cent per annum on Oct 1 next year.

It is a "perennial erroneous assumption" that all FA reps work on a purely transactional basis and would pursue commission over service to the client; and the CPF member would have to be savvy enough to make the investment decisions himself.

Currently, financial advisers can charge a wrap fee of up to 1 per cent of assets under management (AUM) a year for CPFIS members with wrap accounts. This fee covers advisory services and the costs of maintaining the account.

For this round, there is no change to the total expense ratio (TER) which stands at up to 1.75 per cent pa. The TER consists of primarily annual management fees. The more actively managed the fund, the higher the TER.

Many financial experts and retail investors have welcomed the move as the fees are a "drag" on investment return and the eventual removal of the sales charge ensures that every dollar invested goes straight into the fund and earns a return.

It also serves to remove the incentive for financial advisers to sell products under CPFIS merely to earn more commissions. This practice of "churning" - the buying and selling of products - benefits financial advisers at the expense of the investor.

However, Mr Yeo told The Sunday Times that it is a "perennial erroneous assumption" that all FA reps work on a purely transactional basis and would pursue commission over service to the client; and the CPF member would have to be savvy enough to make the investment decisions himself.

Mr Choo noted that given the eventual scenario of only 0.4 per cent per annum wrap or advisory fee, FA reps will only be compensated $40 annually, paid over four quarters for an investment of $10,000.

"While FAs are generally expected to serve their clients' interest, they also need to bear cost and ensure their business is viable. The 0.4 per cent, which is actually the charge applicable to the online model presently, should not be applied to a model with advice and service," said Mr Choo.

"It is likely then CPFIS investors with smaller investible funds will no longer be served by FAs. Only investors with larger investible funds may be willing to pay additional fees by cash if they have already been using FAs and have benefited from it."
Mr Choo suggests that it would be good to continue giving CPF investors the option of investing their funds online on their own or via FAs.

"Cap the sales charge at 1 per cent, and the wrap or advisory fee at 0.5 per cent... Leave it to the investors and the FAs to agree on the actual fees. These figures are neither too big nor too small and there would be some FAs who would be sufficiently incentivised to continue serving the CPFIS investors," said Mr Choo.
He added that these figures are also unlikely to encourage overselling, misselling and churning. Besides, there are measures in place to detect and punish such practices.
